posts.cooked: For teams that have switched to Onshape how has it been? My team is currently thinking about switching to Onshape but we still have big concern especially with not having that much prior knowledge in Onshape compared to our extensive knowledge in SolidWorks.

link_counts.title: Resons for my team why to stay with solidworks

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Depends a lot on the institutional background your team has with Solidworks.

My team moved to Onshape a couple of years ago. Made sense since we were starting from scratch after the pandemic, and kids all have Chromebooks. I love having access to the team CAD on any device without any downloads. But it is dependent on the internet and browser performance.

If your team has a lot of mentors and students who are proficient at SW, it may be hard to switch over.

posts.name: Jonathan Mi
posts.cooked:
Might be a hot take, but for FRC , OnShape is hands down the winner, regardless of mentor or student CAD proficiency in other programs . The FRC specific featurescripts, real-time Google Docs like collaboration, git like branching, MKCAD parts library, ability to run on any device without an install, and plethora of FRC specific training resources makes it a no brainer. 3647 switched from Solidworks to OnShape in 2020 and hasn’t looked back.

If you’re already proficient in Solidworks, OnShape is pretty easy to pick up - the interface are quite similar (OnShape was actually developed by ex-Solidworks employees), with the biggest difference being the part studio workflow and assembly mating system.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Right now our build space has surprisingly unreliable internet (but is otherwise amazing), so that’s a big reason I don’t want browser based CAD, but…

Google docs like simultaneous editing: I’ve never found it helpful to have multiple people editing the same section of a google doc at the same time. I don’t see how it would be that different with CAD, it’s not like Solidworks prevents you from having multiple people work on different parts at once. Sure I can see a few areas where it would be nice to let multiple people update assemblies without check files in and out, but not exactly a game changer.

MKCAD Parts Library: Great, but it is very easy to maintain your own parts library. When you want to use a component that isn’t already in your library, chances are you already have the product page open to download the CAD. So it’s a bit more convenient to let someone else maintain the library, but it’s not hard to maintain your own, and it gives you control over the files to add parts that are common on your team but not from a normal vendor, or modify the CAD of COTS component to make it easier to use.

Browser based: This is a double edged sword, what if I don’t have an internet connection at a competition or want to work while traveling without jump from Wi-Fi to Wi-Fi? With SolidWorks all this means is I cant check parts in or out, if there was nothing saved locally, I’d have to just live without CAD until I find good Wi-Fi.

FRC specific training materials: Yep most FRC specific CAD training materials are in OnShape, but there are huge amounts of SolidWorks training materials free on the internet. I see lots of reasons for FRC specific design training and CAD training specific to your software. I don’t see that much reason why they need to be combined. When I want to teach CAD, I want to teach good drawing practices, and the specific features that are relevant to our team’s fabrication processes (IE 2.5D plates, milled tube and billet, and 3D printing). When I want to teach mechanism design I want to focus on how to understand and design structures and motion, not how best to CAD each component.

I have no problem with Onshape, but the only major advantage I see is not needing a decent windows computer. Getting every student a Windows PC isn’t hard for our team, so that’s less of a problem than risking CAD outages whenever the Wi-Fi is acting up. It’s also probably easier for a team with very limited CAD/design mentors to just send their students to the spectrum and citrus training materials, then just tell them to google their way to good CAD practices, but this advantage goes away if you’re going to have a mentor teaching basic CAD best practices and overseeing the robot design. So use whatever fits your needs, but these advantages are really pretty minor for teams who don’t have problem getting computers or dedicating a mentor to CAD.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

Google docs like simultaneous editing: I’ve never found it helpful to have multiple people editing the same section of a google doc at the same time. I don’t see how it would be that different with CAD, it’s not like Solidworks prevents you from having multiple people work on different parts at once. Sure I can see a few areas where it would be nice to let multiple people update assemblies without check files in and out, but not exactly a game changer.

We’ve found it useful for updating part names/properties when making BOMs. Really though the big advantage of the 'Google Docs" like editing is never needing to save. I cannot begin to describe how much work we lost over the years when SolidWorks crashed before (or sometimes during) a save.

Patrick3357:

MKCAD Parts Library: Great, but it is very easy to maintain your own parts library. When you want to use a component that isn’t already in your library, chances are you already have the product page open to download the CAD. So it’s a bit more convenient to let someone else maintain the library, but it’s not hard to maintain your own, and it gives you control over the files to add parts that are common on your team but not from a normal vendor, or modify the CAD of COTS component to make it easier to use.

MKCAD may not have everything I need, but it’s easy enough to download the things it doesn’t have here and there. The nice part is not needing to spend my limited time and energy on maintaining an up to date library, and never having to deal with issues when inevitably a student accidentally causes an issue with a shared file.

Patrick3357:

but these advantages are really pretty minor

I couldn’t disagree more, Onshape is just so much easier for getting my students up and running using CAD. There’s just too many advantages over SolidWorks. Not needing to save, easy collaboration, not needing to maintain a file structure, intuitive multi-body design, ease of sharing CAD outside our time, baked in FRC part libraries, featurescripts… the list goes on and on.

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked:
With regards to the Google docs simultaneous editing think of this example: One person designing the intake One person going through the drivetrain BOM to pull parts for assembling one person downloading STL files for 3d printing One person creating a drawing for an axle to take to the lathe operator One person using the shooter assembly to see how to assemble it One person doing a design review of a mechanism and leaving comments for the next version

This is the advantage of the way onshape can collaborate thanks to the Google docs style. Having used it and SolidWorks I am fully sold on how easy it is to use onshape really productively and introduce more students to mechanical design.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
Love Onshape for all the mentioned reasons.

Wish it would generate CAM/G code for the OMIO.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.custom_user_title: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: You can easily have 6 people doing those 6 things simultaneously in Solidworks too. Teams using Solidworks have file management systems, so everyone can open parts and assemblies at the same time on their own computers. The only difference is if two people edit the same file at the same time one will get overwritten, which is why good file management systems force you to check out a file to make edits. Like I said, I have no problem with Onshape, it isn’t ideal for our team, but that doesn’t mean it isn’t great for most teams.

posts.name: William Harris
posts.cooked:
not needing to spend my limited time and energy on maintaining an up to date library

Maybe I’m missing something big but library maintenance was never really a particularly sizable time investment when I was working with SolidWorks for FRC . Turns out the COTs parts I’m most likely to need most of the time is basic hardware (screws, nuts and the like) which doesn’t really change that much if at all, or perhaps things like gears, which also are pretty consistent. If I did find that I was missing something it was just a matter of download the model and put it in an appropriate folder and that was pretty much the end of that. It’s nice that MKCAD has it all handled already, but it never felt like that big of a deal to me.

posts.name: Stephen Kalogiannis
posts.cooked: Is onshape free, or is there fees associated with it we use solid works but would consider onshape if it’s free to use?

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Yes it is free (both to teams and to individuals). I would recommend signing up for an Educator Plan with a team-owned account. It really makes it simple to get everyone running.

link_counts.title: Onshape Educator Plan: What it Means for FRC Teams

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

Google docs like simultaneous editing: I’ve never found it helpful to have multiple people editing the same section of a google doc at the same time.

This year, a student created a master sketch for our robot design. I could see their progress in real time, and we iterated on the dimensions around 5 times in a few hours completely remotely, with me providing direction on what to try changing and how to approach it, sometimes with me directly editing the sketch as an example. This is the first time our team has had a master sketch. As far as I can tell, this entire process would not have happened without collaborative editing (and the ease to install Onshape), or would have greatly slowed down our build.

To answer the OP’s question, if you are happy with your current CAD system, stick with it. However, if you feel like it’s a constant battle to teach enough people CAD so that they make useful contributions to the robot design, Onshape may help with that. The teams Solidworks makes sense for are teams where there’s considerable structure around CAD teaching (e.g. students learn it in class or there’s multiple experienced mentors who teach CAD).

one thing we found helpful this year was that now everyone can access and look at the cad.

This meant that programming could pull up the cad whenever they wanted to look at arm weight for a ff calculation, the angle needed for the arm or speaker, electrical could figure out wire routing through tubing, where everything would get mounted, etc.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
Patrick3357:

Right now our build space has surprisingly unreliable internet (but is otherwise amazing), so that’s a big reason I don’t want browser based CAD

Completely and totally fair. No one is forcing anyone to use Onshape. For most of my teams, access to internet is easier than access to moderately powerful computers. Browser-based has allowed us to easily have every student who wants to try CAD be able to in minutes. This does have a downside, but I hardly find myself somewhere without internet when I need to CAD. The worst time for me was being on a plane traveling for work and not wanting to pay $20 for in-flight wifi.

Patrick3357:

I don’t see how it would be that different with CAD, it’s not like Solidworks prevents you from having multiple people work on different parts at once. Sure I can see a few areas where it would be nice to let multiple people update assemblies without check files in and out, but not exactly a game changer.

It’s certainly not necessary to what we do in FRC , but having parts and assemblies update in real-time has been a huge boom to teams I work with seeing the development of the CAD and most importantly WHY specific changes were made. Even if not editing, students can log in and follow along with other students or mentors to see exactly what they are doing live, what buttons they are pressing, etc.

Patrick3357:

MKCAD Parts Library: Great, but it is very easy to maintain your own parts library.

A team who has no design mentors familiar with CAD would hardly find this easy. What about rookie students? The barrier to entry is drastically lowered by a centralized library. The crowd-sourced library also makes the small efforts of everyone supporting the library help all other team using it. MKCAD, while not perfect, has nearly every FRC specific component with weights and part numbers. That’s thousands of components that any team can use in mere minutes.

The usefulness of the FRC specific and other non- FRC specific feature scripts cannot be overstated. These are features that create complex geometries or repetitive patterns in seconds when even experienced users could take minutes to do the same thing. Lighten, tube converter, motor mounting hole pattern, gusset generator, and many more allow teams to focus on the much more interesting problems and avoid inspiration-killing tedious repetitive actions.

Onshape is not the ideal solution for many teams, and that is each team’s choice, but it is the right choice for the vast majority of teams who otherwise lack the resources and knowledge. I believe Onshape has helped level the playing field in designing competitive robots.

posts.name: Asaphfirst
posts.cooked:
Onshape was very good for us until this season.

I wanted to hear from other teams, but working on our Robot assembly was very frustrating. It’d take minutes to load, and it was very laggy. It made the last half of the build season so frustrating.

We tried everything that we found about improving performance, and our internet at school is very good.

Has anyone experienced something similar? When we open individual subsystems it works ok, not amazing but it’s ok.

Our laptops are zbook firefly with nvidia graphic cards.

I’m happy to share our CAD if anyone would like to help us.

Thanks

posts.name: Neel M
posts.cooked:
Basically, to cut down on load times you really need to keep in mind of your overall primitive count as well as your “total regeneration time”.and you can see a breakdown of how long onshape takes to make each one of your changes.

To keep your part studio’s regeneration time down low, you should really keep in mind your usage of resource heavy features like Tube Converter, Belt and Pulley generator, as well as massive gear generators. Try to get all of the same size tubes from the same tube converter featurescript, as well as trying to use less derived features. Belt and pulley is also big resource heavy as the tooth count increases. For tips on how to better optimize your Featurescripts, I would check out this video , where you can see that he only uses a single tube converter featurescript, and instead uses features like transform, mirror, and circular pattern. (Channels also really good for FRC Design in general).

For assemblies, you need to keep your primitive count low.

Heres an example of a pretty well optimized robot for the DDS Cadathon on the 2023 Offseason, 1421 Liftoff . Even though this robot was relatively complex, the primitive count is just under 2.2 million . For reference, one full detail MK4i Module is 1.63 million primitives, and the simplified models we used are simply 95,425 primitives.

image 1920×977 87.6 KB image 1926×1092 170 KB

image 1920×977 87.6 KB

image 1920×977 87.6 KB

image 1926×1092 170 KB

image 1926×1092 170 KB

A few things we did to lower our primitive count in our assemblies were using simplified swerve modules, electronics, and motors from @AndrewCard https://parts.frccad.com .

For more information on primitives and general Onshape load times, heres a reading . Btw, I don’t mind looking at your cad and seeing where you can improve

Break things out into subassemblies and even into separate documents can help with loading times. This way you can work on only the section of interest and do not need to load the rest. It also has the advantage of getting more version control granularity.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Sumter Link
posts.cooked: Love onshape, since switching to it our team’s CADing ability and the number of students actually CADing has increased significantly.  If your school has a PLTW engineering program onshape will even set up an exchange for you and you can create a team for your robotics students, it allows you to share designs super easy.  This year was the first year we used an exchange and it is without a doubt the best the team has ever incoporated CAD into the design process.

posts.name: Joe Schmo
posts.cooked: we just pop downloaded dxfs into carbide create and carbide motion.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked:
four:

Break things out into subassemblies and even into separate documents can help with loading times. This way you can work on only the section of interest and do not need to load the rest. It also has the advantage of getting more version control granularity

This is the real performance trick. Once you hit the performance ceiling for a single document, your best bet is to split out into multiple documents, and use derived and in-context geometry for the subassemblies. These also have the advantage of being based on a version, which is less expensive to load for Onshape than a live model, which needs to be regularly synced.

We hit extreme performance issues about three weeks into the season, and made an emergency pivot to multi-doc. From there it was not a huge problem.

Link2815:

This year was the first year we used an exchange and it is without a doubt the best the team has ever incoporated CAD into the design process.

What is an “exchange” that Onshape set up for you? Is this their Educator account program or something else? I am not familiar with the term.
